It is well known that the selectivity toward different products in furfural hydrogenation can be changed when Ni catalysts are promoted with Fe. To achieve this effect, both elements must be sufficiently close to each other to allow and modify the carbonyl group adsorption mode. This condition is fulfilled if Ni and Fe are alloyed. In this study, the presence of these alloys was confirmed using Mössbauer spectroscopy at 298 and 13 K on freshly reduced catalysts, where three distinct alloy phases were identified. This result was further supported by TPR assays. This is the first report indicating that the co-impregnation preparation leads to this heterogeneity in the catalysts. To verify the effect of these Ni-Fe alloys, the selectivity and activity in furfural hydrogenation were analysed. The changes in the production of furfuryl alcohol, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and furan using a Ni monometallic catalyst and three bimetallic catalysts with different Fe loadings, were observed. The amount of furfuryl alcohol obtained increased significantly with the addition of Fe. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NiFe/SiO2 catalysts NiFe alloys phases Mössbauer spectroscopy Furfural hydrogenation Selective furfuryl alcohol production Abbreviations FAL furfural FOL furfuryl alcohol THFOL tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol THFAL tetrahydrofurfural F furan 2-MF 2-methylfuran THF tetrahydrofuran Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Furfural (FAL) is considered as a platform molecule for the synthesis of a great number of chemicals for a wide range of applications. One significant process in the FAL conversion is its hydrogenation. This reaction leads to the production of valuable chemicals, such as furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL) and 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [1]. Considering that about 62% of global FAL production is used to obtain FOL by hydrogenation, it can be concluded that this is its most important and extended application [2]. The largest FOL use is in the manufacture of foundry resins [3], but this compound is also used in diverse areas such as flavouring, components of motor fuels, pharmaceutical industry, biochemistry, etc [4]. During the hydrogenation of FAL to FOL several side reactions can occur. Therefore, an adequate control of the reaction selectivity by an appropriate catalyst design is highly desirable. Cu-Cr alloys (copper chromite, CuCr2O4-CuO) with or without alkali earth metal promoters (CaO or BaO) are used as industrial catalysts to produce FOL in batch reactors. Typical operation conditions are 453 K and 70-100 bar [5]. The requirement of high hydrogen pressure is the major drawback of this process. Besides chromium (VI) harmful effects for the environment and the difficulties with handling and disposal of used catalyst are widely known. On the other hand, minor quantities of Cr leaching in the reaction media can contaminate FOL and an exhaustive purification is necessary if the FOL must be used in the pharmaceutical industry. With the aim to overcome these disadvantages, many researches using noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Pt) as catalysts were performed [6-10]. On the other hand, supported catalysts with non-noble metals have been studied as well. Thus, results with Cu, Ni, Fe, Zn, Mo etc. can be found in bibliography. Nevertheless, several difficulties are found with these systems: the catalysts are poisoned by coke deposition, low FOL selectivities, of about 50%, are obtained [11], the active species sintering, and high operation pressure and temperature are required [1]. Some promising results have been reported using supported Co catalysts [1,12]. However, it must be considered that Co price is twice than that of Ni. About ten years ago, Ni promotion with oxophilic metals, especially with iron, have been studied in order to modify the selectivity in the FAL hydrogenation reaction. The main aim of this doping is changing the FAL adsorption mode on Ni surface to drive the hydrogenation to the desired product. Sitthisa and Resasco published a detailed experimental and theoretical study about the use of NiFe/SiO2 catalysts for FAL hydrogenation [13]. They found that the selectivity is markedly modified by the addition of the second metal. But their aim was to obtain 2-MF, suppressing the furan (F) production, and operating in vapour phase (483-523 K, 1 bar). In the same way, Wang et al. reported good 2-MF production (72%) using NiFe/C catalysts working at 453 K and 33 bar [14] while Jaatinen et al. with other type of NiFe/C catalysts obtained a production of 2-MF of 31 % at 503 K and 40 bar [15]. Instead, a good FOL selectivity (90%) was obtained by Chieffi et al. with NiFe/C catalysts in a continuous liquid phase reactor at 423 K [16]. Afterwards, Shao et al. published an article using NiFe catalysts and Mg-Al layer double hydroxides as support precursors [17]. The aim of this work was to obtain pentanediols; however, to achieve this objective, a higher production of FOL as an intermediate product is necessary. They showed that when iron is added to nickel, the production of FOL as an intermediate is effectively increased while the production of THFOL is decreased. Recently, Hasanova et al. [18] reported the use of NiFe nanoparticle alloy catalysts supported on carbon and prepared via the urea-glass route. Under relatively drastic conditions (40 bar, 443 K), they observed a shift in selectivity from THFOL to FOL when NiFe catalysts were used instead of monometallic nickel catalysts, achieving an 85% yield of FOL. From this analysis, it can be concluded that effectively, the iron addition to Ni produces a substantial change in products distribution of FAL hydrogenation. Obviously, this effect can only be achieved if nickel and iron are alloyed, because this is the only way in which the distance between both metals is suitable to reach the η2-(C,O) adsorption mode of FAL as happens with monometallic Ni catalyst. In this way, the oxophilic character of iron can be exploited to change the selectivity of the reaction. Different characterization techniques have been used in the literature with the goal of verifying the production of Ni-Fe alloys in supported nanoparticles. However, discrepant results have been reported. Therefore, more effort is necessary to increase knowledge in this area. Mössbauer spectroscopy is an appropriate technique for this purpose. In the early 1980s several authors used this method to identify the alloying between Ni and Fe in nanoparticles supported on different solids such as SiO2, Al2O3, C, TiO2, MgO, etc. [19-22]. Primarily, these catalysts were used in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, and these publications coincide with a period during which renewed interest in this process emerged. The authors used different cell models to perform the measurements after reduction treatment in a controlled atmosphere. However, their devices did not allow them to obtain spectra at low temperatures. Therefore, superparamagnetic relaxation prevailed, preventing the adequate identification of the present species. After this time, significant articles related to this subject did not appear until recently, when Shi and col. published a series of detailed papers in which supported NiFe nanoparticles, intended for fine chemical reactions, were characterized after the reduction step in a controlled atmosphere at 5 K [23-25]. To perform these measurements, it was necessary to transfer the reduced sample to a cryostat in an Ar-filled glove box to avoid contact with air. In this article, we measured the Mössbauer spectra of the reduced NiFe/SiO2 catalysts at 13 and 298 K using a hand-made cell specially designed and built for this purpose [26]. This device allows both the reduction and the placement of the cell within the cryogen without needing to transfer the sample. As a result, the measurement is conducted in the same reduction atmosphere (pure H2). This approach simplifies the handling process and ensures that the spectra are representative of the freshly reduced catalysts. These results were further reinforced by performing TPR assays. Considering the relevance of FOL production, as previously described, we chose the FAL hydrogenation to achieve high selectivity towards FOL as a test reaction. This reaction was used to investigate the effect of adding iron to nickel in order to change the selectivity results. To this end, we use NiFe catalysts supported on SiO2 operating under mild conditions (393 K, 10 bar) in a liquid phase. Hydrogenation in the liquid phase offers several advantages, such as decreasing unwanted side products and lowering energy consumption in the process 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The NiFe/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness co-impregnation method, using an aqueous solution containing both metal precursors: Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%, Merck) and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (99%, Merck). In all cases the pH of the solutions was maintained below 3 in order to avoid possible production of oxyhydroxides. Before impregnation, the silica support (SiO2 Evonik, Sg =180 m2/g, Vp = 1.3 cm3/g, 25 Mesh) was calcined 2 h at 773 K in air in order to eliminate volatile impurities. The Ni nominal loading was kept constant at 10 % wt. in all samples, while three different Fe loadings were used: 3, 6 and 10 % wt. Besides, a monometallic nickel catalyst, with the same metallic percentage was prepared. The catalysts were named: 10Ni, 10Ni3Fe, 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe. After impregnation, the solids were first dried overnight at room temperature and then in an oven at 383 K for 24 h. Finally, prior to its use the catalysts were activated in pure H2 flow (30 cm3/min) at a heating rate of 10 K/min from room temperature to 773 K and maintained for 2 h at the latter. The reduction temperature was selected based on the TPR results described below. A calcination step, before reduction, was not performed because it has been demonstrated that the decomposition of nickel nitrate in a hydrogen atmosphere leads to maximize nickel surface area and its reduction [27]. Nickel contents were determined by a gravimetric method, precipitating the Ni2+ species with the organic compound dimethylglyoxime. On the other hand, a spectrophotometric determination of iron with o-phenanthroline to assert the iron loadings was used. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption at 77 K, Mössbauer spectroscopy in controlled atmosphere at 13 and 298 K, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), hydrogen chemisorption and volumetric oxidation. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 V1.02 E device was used to measure the textural properties: specific surface area (Sg) and specific pore volume (Vp). Mössbauer spectra were obtained in transmission geometry using a 512-channel constant acceleration spectrometer (WissEl, Starnberg, Germany), with a source of 57Co in Rh matrix with 50 mCi of nominal activity. The ideal thickness of the sample was evaluated considering the weight percentages of the different elements (ca. 100 mg of powder were used in a sample holder with a diameter of ca. 1.8 cm). A 12-μm-thick α-Fe foil was used as reference for velocity calibration. Spectra were collected at 13 and 298 K. Measurements at low temperatures were performed with a closed-cycle cryogenic system (Model DE-202, ARS, Macungie, PA, USA). Each spectrum was folded to minimize geometric effects. The experimental data were fitted using Recoil [28], commercial software with constraints. The size distributions of the metallic nanoparticles were determined by TEM (JEOL 100 Cx). Before the analysis, the samples were reduced using the same conditions for the activation process. The reduced catalysts, handled ex situ, were grounded, suspended in bidistilled water, sonicated, deposited onto TEM grids (Cu), and dried. Microphotographs were obtained in bright-field mode. The TPR assays were performed in a Quantachrome equipment (Quantasorb Jr model) using 100 mg of catalyst and a mixture of 10% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 20 cm3/min. The solids were heated up from room temperature to 1073 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. Hydrogen adsorption measurements were carried out in a conventional Pyrex glass static volumetric adsorption apparatus. The quantification of total H2 uptake at 323 K was obtained extrapolating the linear portion of the isotherm to zero pressure. It has been demonstrated that in these conditions, hydrogen monolayer adsorption capacity can be measured in a reliable way in Ni/SiO2 systems with metallic loadings of about 10 % wt, with a stoichiometry of one hydrogen atom per surface nickel atom [29]. On the other hand, more recent results indicate that in bimetallic Ni-Fe supported catalysts, H2 is only chemisorbed on the surface Ni atoms when the mentioned conditions are used [30,31]. After H2 chemisorption measurements, all samples were evacuated and the total pure O2 consumption, necessary to reoxidize the catalysts, was measured at 623 K in order to determine the reduction degree of the species. 2.2 Catalytic measurements Catalytic hydrogenation reactions of FAL were carried out in a batch reactor, autoclave type, during 7 h using 10 bar of H2 pressure, at 393 K. In each test, 250 mg of catalyst, 1 mL of FAL and 50 mL of 2-propanol as solvent were used. The reaction products were analysed by gas chromatography in a Varian CP-3800 chromatograph equipped with a FID detector and a CP wax 52 CB capillary column (30 m x 0.53 mm I.D.). Compounds identification was performed by mass spectrometry, in a Shimadzu QP5050 GC/MS equipment with a SUPELCO SPBTM-5 capillary column (30m x 0.25 mm I.D.). FAL conversion and selectivity to each product were calculated as follows: F u r f u r a l C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( N 0 − N t N 0 ) x 100 N0: number of initial FAL moles. Nt: number of not consumed FAL moles at reaction time t. S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = N i ∑ i = 1 n N i Ni: number moles of “i” product. ∑ i = 1 n N i : total number moles of all obtained products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization In Table I metal loadings and textural properties of NiFe/SiO2 catalysts are reported. A decrease on the specific surface area and the pore volume of the support is noted, indicating that metallic nanoparticles are located inside and/or obstructing a fraction of the silica pores. In order to identify the species present in the bimetallic activated fresh catalysts, the Mössbauer spectra at 298 and 13 K were measured. To avoid possible reoxidations, the spectra were acquired in the same reduction atmosphere (pure H2) using a hand-made cell specially designed and built for this purpose [26]. The spectra at 298 and 13 K are displayed in Figs 1 and 2 respectively. At room temperature all spectra showed four peaks and a broad central line. Besides, the existence of a curved background (the valleys between the peaks do not get the values of the baseline) indicates the presence of magnetic relaxation of the present species. For this reason, the spectra were obtained at 13 K with the aim to block this relaxation and to get a simpler interpretation. However, at this low temperature the magnetic relaxation process has not disappeared completely. The spectrum of 10Ni3Fe at 298 K was fitted with three relaxing sextets whose hyperfine parameters are shown in Table II . The signal with higher hyperfine magnetic field (blue line) has hyperfine parameters typical of a Ni-Fe alloy in a α-b.c.c. phase [32-34]. The second sextet (red line) can be assigned to another phase of a Ni-Fe alloy: γ-f.c.c. in a high spin state [32-35]. Finally, the central collapsed sextet (green line) shows hyperfine parameters and an evolution, when the temperature decreases at 13 K, that can be ascribed to a paramagnetic Ni-Fe alloy with a very low antiferromagnetic ordering temperature (Neel temperature of about 25-30 K) and a small hyperfine magnetic field (15-30 kOe) [36]. Scorzelli and dos Santos identified this phase as γ-low spin (γLS) Ni-Fe alloy with an approximate 28% Ni composition [37]. It must be clarified that the presence of particle size distributions leads to a distribution of magnetic hyperfine fields (H) due to the dependence of this value on the particle size [38]. Therefore, the H values reported in this work are average values, denoted as <H>. The same species were detected in 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe. In order to get a good fitting of the experimental spectra, it was necessary to include a central doublet (magenta line) (Table II). This doublet could be assigned to iron oxides in a superparamagnetic relaxation regime (α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3 and/or Fe3O4) [39,40] or to isolated paramagnetic Fe3+ ions [41]. The measurements at 13 K allowed us to eliminate some of these possibilities, as is described below. The spectra acquired at 13 K showed the same species detected at 298 K (Table III ). Nevertheless, in 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe, the doublets corresponding to Fe3+ species displayed a partial magnetic blocking (magenta lines). This behaviour is typical of very small iron oxides particles which are in a superparamagnetic relaxation regime at room temperature. The absence of a complete blocking of the magnetic relaxation prevents an identification of the actual iron oxide species present. Nonetheless, taking into account that the 2ε values of these interactions are approximately equals to zero we could assign it to the presence of γ-Fe2O3 and/or Fe3O4 [40]. This attribution will be reinforced with the TPR results as it will be described below. Is important to remark that the quadrupole splitting of the doublets assigned to superparamagnetic iron oxides at 298 K is very high. This result would indicate that a large number of the iron atoms that generate these oxide clusters are located at the surface. Therefore, it can be speculated that in 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe about 15 % of the total iron loading is segregated on the surface of the particles of the Ni-Fe alloy, which could be producing small oxide “patches”. Previous reports indicate that Fe100−xNix alloys with x < 30 consist only of b.c.c. phase, while an f.c.c phase appears as x increases beyond this value and a single f.c.c. phase is observed for x > 40 [32]. Considering the metallic loadings of our catalysts, the following atomic compositions would be obtained: Fe23Ni77, Fe37Ni63, Fe51Ni49. Therefore, only f.c.c. phase should be detected. However, the Mössbauer results showed three different Ni-Fe phases. Through the use of magnetic hyperfine fields vs. Ni percentage plot published by Dumpich et al. [33] we can estimate that the α-b.c.c. phase could have a composition between Fe90Ni10 and Fe70Ni30. On the other hand, the composition of the γ-f.c.c. in a high spin state phase should be found between Fe37Ni63 and Fe25Ni75. Finally, as it was previously discussed, the composition of paramagnetic γ-f.c.c. in a low spin state phase would be, approximately, Fe72Ni28. These results, clearly, indicate that the Ni-Fe alloy has not a homogeneous composition in the catalysts. Taking into account that in the three bimetallic catalysts, nanoparticles have a size distribution between 5 and 20 nm approximately, we can suppose that α-b.c.c. and γ-f.c.c. phases would be produced in particles with different sizes. However, the present results do not allow us to assign the different phases to a determined particle size. The paramagnetic γ-f.c.c. in a low spin state phase would be located in the same nanoparticles in which γ-f.c.c. in a high spin state phase is found, given that it has been previously reported the existence of the first phase intergrowth with the second one [37]. In summary, in 10Ni3Fe catalyst, total iron loading is alloyed with Ni in three different phases: α-b.c.c., γ-f.c.c. in a high spin state and paramagnetic γ-f.c.c. in a low spin state. The same species were detected in 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe but, in both systems about 15% of the iron content was not incorporated into the Ni-Fe alloy. This iron fraction appears segregated as clusters of γ-Fe2O3 and/or Fe3O4. In Fig. 3 , both the TEM micrographs and the corresponding particle size distributions for the four catalysts are reported. In Table IV the average particle sizes obtained by fitting the size histograms with log-normal distributions are displayed. We use this type of function in agreement with previous studies showing that particles too small to display a crystal habit (i.e. lower than 20 nm) present a log-normal size distribution [42]. Fittings are shown as continuous lines drawn on the histogram graphs. As it can be seen, iron addition did not produce significant modifications on the average particle sizes. This result strengthens the conclusion that both iron species (alloyed with Ni and segregated as γ-Fe2O3 and/or Fe3O4) are located in the nickel particles. Since, it would be unlikely that iron oxide nanoparticles isolated were generated presenting the same size as nickel-iron alloy particles [25]. In Fig. 4 the TPR diagrams are shown. The monometallic Ni catalyst (10Ni) displays three reduction signals which were deconvoluted with five gaussian peaks. In Table V the corresponding maximum temperatures are reported. The first peak (green line) at 575 K can be assigned to the simultaneous decomposition and reduction of nitrate anion with little or no support interaction [27,43]. This process takes place within a very narrow temperature range (of about 20 K). The following H2 consumption occurred in two steps (two peaks were necessary to get a good fitting, magenta lines) at 605 and 662 K. These consumptions can be attributed to the reduction of NiO (produced after nitrate decomposition) with different crystal sizes: the larger, with lower support interaction, are more easily reduced than the smaller one [27]. As it was mentioned previously (TEM results) these different sizes would correspond to distinct fractions of the size distribution. Finally, two weak peaks appear at 743 and 813 K (wine lines) which can be assigned to the reduction of superficial nickel hydroxysilicates [13,44]. The reduction of these species represents about 15% of the total H2 consumption of the reducible nickel species (without considering NO3 - reduction/decomposition) and they are not reduced in the activated catalyst. This percentage is in a good agreement with the volumetric oxidation result as it is shown below. H2 consumptions evaluated from the TPR areas are shown in Table IV. Again, the NO3 - peaks were not considered in this evaluation because in this step occurs a simultaneous reduction and decomposition of these species. Therefore, H2 consumption cannot be evaluated. The 10Ni3Fe TPR diagram showed differences with the monometallic catalyst. The first signal appears broadened and two peaks were included to achieve a good fitting (green lines). We attributed this behaviour to slight differences between decomposition/reduction temperatures of the different metallic nitrates. On the other hand, a more important change is detected in the second signal, in which only one reduction step occurred with a maximum at 636 K (blue line). Taking into account that the two remaining peaks at high temperatures did not show changes neither their maximum temperatures nor relative areas, we can conclude that the H2 consumption at 636 K can be assigned to the simultaneous reduction of nickel and iron species that leads to the formation of an alloy [24]. If segregated iron species would be present, they should display a principal H2 consumption between 860 and 1000 K [13] although the presence of metallic nickel could decrease these temperatures somewhat, due to its ability to produce atomic hydrogen. Therefore, the absence of modifications in the peaks at ≅ 740 and 810 K, allow us to conclude that all iron loading is reduced together with nickel to produce a NiFe alloy at 636 K. This description is in agreement with the Mössbauer results because in this catalyst, segregated iron oxide species were not detected. The only difference between 10Ni3Fe and 10Ni6Fe TPRs is a noticeable increase in the area of the 740 K peak (red line). In this system the reduction of these species represents about 30% of the total H2 consumption of the reducible species. We have attributed this effect to the reduction of Fe3O4, segregated from the alloys to α-Fe [45]. This tendency is maintained in 10Ni10Fe, however the high temperature reduction peak now represents about 37% of the total H2 consumption of the reducible species. Besides, a small peak at low temperature (about 590 K, red line) assignable to the reduction of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 is detected. This process was not distinguished in 10Ni6Fe (which has lower iron loading and lower quantity of segregated iron species) because only 1 mol of H2 is consumed to reduce 3 moles of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Instead, 4 moles of H2 are required to reduce 1 mol of Fe3O4 to α-Fe. Therefore it is easier to detect the last reduction step in comparison with the first one by means of TPR. Considering the typical decomposition and reduction steps of an inorganic iron salt (iron salt → α-Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → α-Fe) and the detection of Fe3O4 production by TPR in 10Ni6Fe and 10Ni10Fe, we can discard the presence of γ-Fe2O3 in both fresh reduced catalysts. Considering that the catalysts were activated at 773 K during 2 h, Fe3O4 species would not be completely reduced. In Table IV the H2 chemisorption and volumetric oxidation results are displayed. The H2 chemisorbed quantity for 10Ni was used to calculate the percentage dispersion (%D) assuming that the chemisorption stoichiometry is H/Nisurf = 1 [46] and discounting the minor nickel percentage not reduced (about 10%) according to the volumetric oxidation results (Table IV). A value of D = 8.5% was obtained. This quantity was used to calculate the metallic nickel average particle size with the following expression: 〈 d ( n m ) 〉 N i 0 = 9.71 % D as it was suggested by Bartholomew et al. [46]. These authors assumed that all metallic nickel nanoparticles are spherical with the same diameter, and they calculated a site density of 6.77 × 10-2 nm2/atom based on an equal distribution of the three lowest index planes of nickel (f.c.c.). In this way, we have obtained a value of 11.4 nm. The excellent agreement between this result and the average particle size obtained from TEM (12.9 nm, Table IV) indicates that the present measurements are reliable to determine the number of surface metallic Ni sites. The same size estimation is not applicable for the bimetallic catalysts because the H2 chemisorption stoichiometry on NiFe alloys is unknown [22]. Nevertheless, taking into account that in our experimental conditions a negligible H2 quantity is chemisorbed on metallic surface iron, the values of Table IV allow us to conclude that the surface of the NiFe alloy nanoparticles are enriched in Fe when the loading of this metal is increased. This effect leads to a blocking of the active surface nickel sites. Additionally, Table IV reports the experimental O2 consumptions necessary to reoxidize the freshly reduced catalysts, with the theoretical values shown in the adjacent column. To evaluate the theoretical O2 uptake required to reoxidize the activated catalyst, the following stoichiometries and assumptions were taken into account: For monometallic catalyst: N i 0 + 1 / 2 O 2 → NiO The Ni that produces hydroxysilicates is excluded because the activation process does not reach the temperature necessary to reduce these species. The percentage of Ni hydroxysilicates is obtained from the TPR areas. For bimetallic catalysts, the following general stoichiometry is assumed: 4 N i 0 F e 0 + 5 O 2 → 4 NiO + 2 F e 2 O 3 It is assumed that Ni-Fe alloys contain both metals in their zerovalent state. Additionally, Ni hydroxysilicates (determined by TPR) and the percentage of segregated Fe3O4 (determined by Mössbauer spectroscopy) were excluded from the total metal loadings. It is also assumed that the percentage of segregated Fe3O4 was reoxidized to Fe2O3 according to: 2 F e 3 O 4 + 1 / 2 O 2 → 3 F e 2 O 3 It can be seen that, when iron is added, the NiFe alloy is more resistant to reoxidation than Ni alone. 3.2 Catalytic tests In Fig. 5 are schematized the possible reaction pathways for FAL hydrogenation in our reaction conditions. The most abundant products obtained with all catalysts were: FOL, derived from the hydrogenation of carbonyl group, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), from the simultaneous hydrogenation of carbonyl group and furan ring, and furan (F) derived from the decarbonylation reaction. Besides, the following minorities compounds were detected: THFAL, 2-MF, tetrahydrofuran and 2-isopropoxy methyl-furan, the last one produced by reaction between FOL and the solvent used (2-propanol). It should be noted that, under our reaction conditions, a test with monometallic Fe/SiO2 catalyst exhibited no activity for FAL conversion. In Table VI , the FAL conversions after 7 h of reaction and the corresponding selectivities to FOL are reported. It can be seen that the iron presence has modified both activity and selectivity of the catalysts. The activity is slightly increased in 10Ni3Fe and 10Ni6Fe with respect to the monometallic catalyst but, with the higher iron loading (10Ni10Fe), this property falls below 10Ni. These results would indicate that there is an optimum promoter content between 3 and 6 % wt. This result is coherent with Mössbauer, TPR and H2 chemisorption assays which indicates that increasing Fe concentration beyond 6% wt, the increasing Fe3O4 segregation over the surface of the Ni-Fe alloy blocks active sites. A similar behaviour was found when Pt and Ni catalysts were modified adding a more electropositive metal such as Sn in the chemoselective hydrogenation of furfuraldehyde [47]. On the other hand, iron presence produced a significant increment on the FOL selectivity. In order to discard possible effects of conversion level on these results, in Fig. 6 are shown the selectivity diagrams for the four catalysts at isoconversion (25%). For clarity purposes, in this graph, minority products (with selectivities lower than 1.5%) were not represented. In all cases, the principal product is FOL but, effectively, iron adding markedly increases the production of this alcohol. Conversely, percentage of THFOL was notoriously decreased. Considering that this last compound is the result of a complete hydrogenation of FAL, this effect would indicate that the iron presence assists to increase the production of an intermediate hydrogenated compound (FOL). It is important to remark the considerable influence of the reaction conditions on the products distribution in the FAL hydrogenation. Thus, in a detailed study using Ni-Fe/SiO2 catalysts in vapour phase at reaction temperatures between 483-523 K, Sitthisa et al. [13] found an important shifting of the selectivity to 2-MF and decarbonylaton suppression with the adding of iron. Besides, they detected C4 products generated by furanyl ring opening. This reaction is also favoured by the increase in the reaction temperature. In this work, we have not obtained C4 products. Finally, the recyclability of the catalyst 10Ni3Fe (which showed the higher FOL selectivity) was studied under the same reaction conditions, performing a total of three cycles of 7 h each one (Table VII ). The recovered catalyst only was washed with the solvent and then was reused without any other treatment. The activity for FAL hydrogenation showed a decrease of about 17% in the first cycle and this lessening was lower in the second one. This deactivation could be attributed to an irreversible CO adsorption on the metallic surface sites in the present reaction conditions [48]. The CO molecules are produced during the decarbonylation of FAL. CO-TPD experiments on Fe-Ni alloys supported on Al2O3 have shown that chemisorbed CO on these surfaces is desorbed in two steps: at about 500 K and in a range between 673 and 773 K [49]. Another possible deactivation effect would be generated by the oligomers adsorption on the catalyst surface. It is important to remark that in the present work no regeneration method of the used catalyst was carried out. In future research possible regeneration methods, such as washing, drying and reduction in H2 flow will be tested. On the other hand, FOL selectivity remained in high values, decreasing less than 8%. The catalytic results will be discussed below beginning with monometallic catalyst. In order to explain the selectivity to the main products, it is necessary to take into account that is commonly accepted that FAL is adsorbed in a planar mode (Fig. 7 a) on Group VIII metals where aldehyde function acquire an η2-(C,O) configuration with both C and O bounded to two neighbour metal surface atoms [6,13]. Sitthisa et al. performed calculations of Density Functional Theory (DFT) to study the stability of FAL adsorbed on a pure surface of Ni(111) and they found an increase of C-O bond length when the adsorption take place. They explain this behaviour considering that the energy of the π* states of carbonyl decrease below the Ni Fermi level after the adsorption. As consequence, the π backbonding from the 3d Ni states to the carbonyl π* states is facilitated, C-O bond is weakened and the aldehyde hydrogenation success at low temperature [13]. This description would explain our results with 10Ni because in mild reaction conditions (10 bar of H2 pressure and 393 K) FOL is the principal product obtained (≅ 68%). On the other hand, the planar furanyl ring is adsorbed parallel to the metallic surface due to the strong interaction between its delocalized π electrons and the transition metal of the catalyst [6,50]. This powerful adsorption would retain molecules during more time, allowing their complete hydrogenation to tetraydrofurfuryl alcohol. This is the second major product. Finally, the η2-(C,O) adsorption mode can be stabilized by the production of radical η1-(C)-acyl. This species is an intermediate that leads to decarbonylation producing furan and CO. This process has a high activation energy, so it is increased when the reaction temperature is high. This fact would explain the low furan production with 10Ni (about 8%). When iron is added to nickel, the FAL adsorption mode is modified. This can be attributed to the tendency of iron to remove an oxygen atom from organic compounds (oxophilicity). As a consequence, the O-Fe bond length decreases while the C-Ni bond length increases in the aldehyde functional group. Therefore, the η2-(C,O) adsorption mode change from planar to tilted (Fig. 7b). Besides, the length of C-O bond of the aldehyde group is increased. Both effects make easier their hydrogenation. These changes, produced by iron incorporation, would justify the evident increase in the FOL production in comparison with the monometallic catalyst [50]. In the selectivity diagram (Fig. 6), it can be seen that the increase in FOL production when iron is added comes from a notorious decrease in THFOL and, in a lesser degree, in F, in comparison with monometallic catalyst. Taking into account that the FAL molecule is planar, when the adsorption mode η2-(C,O) tilts it relative to the alloy surface, the furanyl group moves away from that surface. Therefore, the interaction between this group and the metallic surface is weakened in comparison with the monometallic catalyst making the complete hydrogenation of FAL to produce tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol more difficult The previous explanation points out a higher interaction of the aldehyde group in comparison with furanyl group in bimetallic catalysts. This effect inhibit the conversion of η2-(C,O)-aldehyde surface species to η1-(C)-acyl species. Therefore, the decarbonylation is significantly reduced in presence of iron and thus, furan production decreases [50]. This description would justify why the increase in FOL production is accompanied by a remarkably diminution of the products obtained by complete dehydrogenation and decarbonylation in bimetallic catalysts. It must be emphazised that the proximity of Ni-Fe atoms, necessary to get η2-(C,O) adsorption mode, is achieved when these metals are alloyed. The production of Ni-Fe alloy was clearly demonstrated by Mössbauer spectroscopy and TPR assays. On the other hand, it is important to mention that all previous work of FAL hydrogenation have considered the existence of only one alloy phase: f.c.c. because in NiFe catalysts the major element is Ni. However, we found the presence of three different phases by Mössbauer spectroscopy. Considering that the face centered and body centered cubic structures have marked differences in the interatomic spacing at both the surface and the bulk, it would be expected that the two Ni-Fe phases exhibit different activity and selectivity to the FAL hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions By adding iron to Ni/SiO2 catalysts, a NiFe alloy is produced, as verified by Mössbauer spectroscopy in a controlled atmosphere at 298 and 13 K. Three different phases of this alloy were detected: α-b.c.c., γ-f.c.c. in a high spin state and γ-f.c.c. in a low spin state. Superficial magnetite segregation occurs in 10NiFe6 and 10NiFe10 blocking some surface sites. To our knowledge, the existence of different nickel-iron alloys phases in this kind of catalysts is reported for the first time. Furfural hydrogenation under mild reaction conditions (393 K and 10 bar of hydrogen) with nickel monometallic and nickel-iron bimetallic catalysts was chosen as the reaction test to verify the effect of Ni-Fe alloying on reaction selectivity. With the monometallic system the main products are furfuryl alcohol and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. Furan production is significantly lower. Bimetallic catalysts showed a significant increase in furfuryl alcohol yield with a noticeable decrease of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and furan percentages. The formation of these alloys allows achieving the nickel-iron proximity necessary for the adsorption of the aldehyde group in the η2-(C,O) mode similar to a monometallic catalyst. However, the iron oxophilicity decreases the distance of the O-Fe bond compared to C-Ni, thus tilting the carbonyl group and increasing the C-O distance. Because of these changes in the adsorption mode, the hydrogenation of aldehyde group become easier leading to increased production of furfuryl alcohol. On the other hand, the furanyl group is drawn away from the alloy surface, decreasing the hydrogenation of this ring. This explains the significant decrease in tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol production. Furthermore, the higher interaction of the aldehyde group compared to the furanyl group inhibits the conversion of η2-(C,O)-aldehyde surface species to η1-(C)-acyl species. Therefore, the decarbonylation is significantly reduced and the furan production decreases. Clearly, the increased production of furfuryl alcohol stems from the decrease in tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and furan caused by iron adding. The most promising catalyst of our study is 10Ni3Fe because it has the higher furfuryl alcohol selectivity. Higher iron loading leads to superficial Fe3O4 segregation, blocking active sites, and decreasing activity. coredata.dc:description: It is well known that the selectivity toward different products in furfural hydrogenation can be changed when Ni catalysts are promoted with Fe. To achieve this effect, both elements must be sufficiently close to each other to allow and modify the carbonyl group adsorption mode. This condition is fulfilled if Ni and Fe are alloyed. In this study, the presence of these alloys was confirmed using Mössbauer spectroscopy at 298 and 13 K on freshly reduced catalysts, where three distinct alloy phases were identified. This result was further supported by TPR assays. This is the first report indicating that the co-impregnation preparation leads to this heterogeneity in the catalysts. To verify the effect of these Ni-Fe alloys, the selectivity and activity in furfural hydrogenation were analysed. The changes in the production of furfuryl alcohol, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and furan using a Ni monometallic catalyst and three bimetallic catalysts with different Fe loadings, were observed. The amount of furfuryl alcohol obtained increased significantly with the addition of Fe.
